abstract.p: Letter from Arthur C Helton (Council on Foreign Relations) says United Nations is having a hard time building peace in Kosovo (July 3 article) because it lacks doctrine of peace-building and institutional framework to ensure that experience gained in one operation can be applied to future ones

block.p: Your July 3 news article about the difficulties of building peace in Kosovo indicates a chronic deficiency in United Nations operations.
Your July 3 news article about the difficulties of building peace in Kosovo indicates a chronic deficiency in United Nations operations.
There is no doctrine of peace-building nor institutional framework to ensure that experience is accumulated so that it may be applied in future operations.

This has resulted in ad hoc approaches that have caused the same ''lessons'' to be identified but not learned in a wide variety of settings over the last decade from northern Iraq to East Timor. Basic system reform will be needed if the United Nations is to succeed in building sustainable peace in war-torn societies in the future.
ARTHUR C. HELTON Senior Fellow Council on Foreign Relations New York, July 6, 2000
